name: jekyll-org
body:
jekyll-org ========== Overview -------- This plugin adds [Org mode](http://orgmode.org/) support to [Jekyll](http://jekyllrb.com) and lets you write posts and pages in Org. Requirements ------------ - Jekyll - org-ruby Installation ------------ 1. Install org-ruby ``` {.bash} $ sudo gem install org-ruby ``` 2. Clone the jekyll-org plugin ``` {.bash} $ git clone http://github.com/eggcaker/jekyll-org.git /path/to/jekyllpath/_plugins/jekyll-org ``` If you want use jekyll-org as a submodule, you can: ``` {.bash} $ cd /path/to/your/jekyll/site/ $ git submodule add http://github.com/eggcaker/jekyll-org.git _plugins/jekyll-org ``` Usage ----- Create a new file with `.org` extesion in `_posts`, and write the post with Org. That is all! Generate your Jekyll site as you usually do. Front matter ------------ Instead of YAML the front matter is configured in the usual Org way, with no lines: ``` {.example} #+TITLE: Jekyll and Org together #+LAYOUT: posts #+TAGS: jekyll org-mode This is a blog post about Jekyll and Org mode. ``` Liquid templating ----------------- By default the all content is exported to raw HTML with org-ruby, but you can add `#+liquid: whatevervalue=` in the header. Then you can use [Liquid](http://docs.shopify.com/themes/liquid-documentation/basics) tags. For example, if your Org file contains ``` {.example} #+liquid: enabled #+foo: hello world {{ page.foo }} or {{ site.time | date_to_xmlschema }} ``` then you will get output like ``` {.example}

hello world

or

2014-07-02T08:20:28+08:00

``` Source code highlighting ------------------------ Add a source code block as you would in Org, for example Ruby: ``` {.example} #+BEGIN_SRC require 'rubygems' require 'org-ruby' data = IO.read(filename) puts Orgmode::Parser.new(data).to_html #+END_SRC ``` Then the output will have code highlighting: ``` {.ruby} require 'rubygems' require 'org-ruby' data = IO.read(filename) puts Orgmode::Parser.new(data).to_html ``` Author ------ eggcaker \ License ------- MIT
